comment.author: 84765021@N00
comment._content: How strange. I wonder why this was censored (presumably this was done by someone at the Bain Service).

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Aboard his yacht, Oneida. Like many boat-owners, E.C. Benedict, a banker, used the same name for more than one yacht, according to the NYT of August 4, 1922, when his second, larger Oneida was sold after his death. He had bought her around 1914. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0DE2DF1339EF3AB... His obituary in the NYT of November 24, 1920 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D01E3DE163CE533A... indicates that his full name was Elias Cornelius Benedict, but he usually went by E.C.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I started a Wikipedia entry for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elias_Cornelius_Benedict

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The yachting magazine "The Rudder" has a long biographical article about him in the June 1916 issue. books.google.com/books?id=nsU6AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA261

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: this photo appears to be dated 11/5/17 unless you think the 7 is a poorly made 2

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: It is my belief that some dates written on the negatives are dates when the pictures were used rather than when they were taken. Since another picture in this batch, www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3238474487/in/s... was almost certainly taken in 1913, I suspect this one was too. On the other hand, in November 1917, Benedict will have been in the news for giving a hospital to Greenwich, Connecticut. See books.google.com/books?id=pGsCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA17&lp... That could also account for the blanking out of the other person.
